metadata.description:
The products of the Antarctic ice sheet extent reflect the continuous dynamic change of the ice sheet, and are the data basis for studying the mass balance, ice sheet freeze-thaw, energy balance, and other studies of the Antarctic ice sheet.
This data is the result of the National Key Research and Development Plan "Global Energy Cycle and Water Cycle Key Parameters Stereoscopic Observation and Remote Sensing Inversion","Remote Sensing Inversion Algorithm and Product Development of Key Parameters of Ice, Snow and Marine Salinity (2018YFA0605403)". It displays the full-range ice sheet cover changes of Antarctica over a fine time scale, for the first time, revealing the seasonal changes of the Antarctic ice sheet under global warming. These datasets provide effective data support for a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of mass loss and rapid glacier and ice shelf calving in the Antarctic ice sheet.

background: The Antarctic ice shelf system is an important area connecting the ice sheets and the ocean. Its stability is closely related to the Antarctic mass balance. Iceberg calving, the shedding of ice from glaciers or ice shelf frontal edges, is the main process contributing to the dynamic mass loss from the ice sheet to the ocean. Iceberg calving accounts for half of the net mass loss of the Antarctic ice shelves. Although iceberg calving plays an important role in the Antarctic ice shelf mass balance, the majority of the current ice sheet and ocean climate models do not represent the calving process in a physically realistic manner. Understanding this process is critical for accurately predicting the future impact of climate change on ice sheets. Currently, extensive and detailed iceberg calving observations are time-consuming and laborious. This is mainly because of the massive volume of high-resolution remotely sensed data and the lack of efficient extraction methods. This has led to a paucity of continuous monitoring of calving events at the continental scale.
research objective: Here, we propose a new and efficient method of separating the expansion and calving processes of ice shelves. One of the main objectives of the detailed monitoring of iceberg calving is to extract the location, shape, area, and mass of each single calving event.
challenges: The difficulties in the precise monitoring of iceberg calving lie with the coexistence of ice shelf advances and calving. The manual location of iceberg calving is time-consuming and painstaking, while achieving precise extraction has mostly relied on the surface textural characteristics of the ice shelves and the quality of the images. However, observing iceberg calving is much more complicated than monitoring changes in the coastline. This is because the expansion of the ice shelves coexists with the calving events, but the changes in the coastline can only reflect the overall advance or retreat of the coastline. This method requires repeated comparisons between the frontal edges in two temporal images to check whether calving has occurred, which is time-consuming and laborious. Moreover, the image matching method for high-precision monitoring is quite demanding in terms of the image’s quality and texture coherence before and after calving.
methods: We processed the Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products using the Sentinel Application Platform (SNAP), developed by Brockmann Consult, SkyWatch and C-S and released by the European Space Agency. After the calibration and terrain correction, we chose the Antarctica polar stereographic projections and resampled to a 75 m resolution. We automatically extracted and manually modified the coastline vector for August 2015 as the original coastline benchmark, using an updated version of the Canny edge detection algorithm. We converted the benchmark ice shelf polygon vertices into points and recorded their order. Then, the following operations were carried out for each point. First, we judged whether the point was on the grounding line or not. Next, based on the velocity of each coastline point, we identified its movement and new location. After joining the points to the line, a new coastline was derived, namely the simulated coastline. By comparing the simulated ice shelf polygon to its contemporaneous images and by correcting the frontal edge of the ice shelf, so that it fits into the actual coastline position, we can obtain the exact ice shelf polygon for the following year. By subtracting the corrected ice shelf polygons from the theoretical simulated polygons, we obtained calved-area polygons during that year.
dataset: The Sentinel-1 EW L1 ground range detected (GRD) products, which repeatedly covered the Antarctic coastline in August each year from 2015 to 2019, were used in our study. The MEaSUREs (Making Earth System Data Records for Use in Research Environments) grounding line dataset version 2, downloaded from the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSDIC) website. We used the MEaSUREs Antarctica Ice Velocity Map Version 2 to obtain the spatial distribution of the ice velocity values.
findings: A total of 2032 annual Antarctic calving events were detected, with areas ranging from 0.05 km2 to 6141.0 km2, occurring on almost every Antarctic ice shelf. The positioning error of the simulated coastline is less than one pixel, and the determined minimum valid extraction area is 0.05 km2, when based on 75 m resolution images. Our method effectively avoids repetition and omission errors during the calved area extraction process.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor iceberg calving events in the Antarctic region?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used to monitor iceberg calving events involves processing Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products with the Sentinel Application Platform (SNAP). After calibration and terrain correction, the data are resampled to a 75 m resolution to automatically extract and manually modify the coastline vector, which helps identify calving events by comparing simulated and contemporaneous images.

Example.Question: Please give an example of a challenge faced in the precise monitoring of iceberg calving and how it might be addressed.
Example.Answer: A challenge in precise monitoring of iceberg calving is the coexistence of ice shelf advances and calving, which makes manual location time-consuming. This can be addressed by using image processing techniques like an updated Canny edge detection algorithm and comparing images to derive new coastlines and calved-area polygons, reducing repetition and omission errors.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of datasets used to analyze the Antarctic ice shelf's movement and changes?
Example.Answer: An example of datasets used includes the Sentinel-1 EW L1 ground range detected (GRD) products, covering the Antarctic coastline, and the MEaSUREs Antarctica Ice Velocity Map Version 2, which provides spatial distribution of ice velocity values to analyze ice shelf movement and changes.

Definition.Question: What does 'iceberg calving' mean in the context of Antarctic ice shelf monitoring?
Definition.Answer: Iceberg calving refers to the shedding of ice from glaciers or ice shelf frontal edges, which is a primary process contributing to the dynamic mass loss from the ice sheet to the ocean. It accounts for half of the net mass loss of the Antarctic ice shelves.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'coastline vector extraction' within the context of Antarctic ice shelf studies?
Definition.Answer: Coastline vector extraction is a process where the coastline is automatically extracted and manually modified to create a vector representation of the ice shelf's frontal edges. This involves using edge detection algorithms to establish a baseline for monitoring ice shelf changes over time.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of monitoring iceberg calving using high-resolution remotely sensed data compare to the challenges of monitoring changes in the coastline?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges of monitoring iceberg calving are more complex than monitoring coastline changes. Iceberg calving involves the coexistence of ice shelf advances and calving, requiring precise extraction methods and repeated comparisons between temporal images. This is time-consuming and relies heavily on image quality and texture coherence. In contrast, monitoring coastline changes primarily reflects the overall advance or retreat of the coastline and does not involve the same level of complexity in distinguishing between advancing and retreating ice.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the method of extracting ice shelf calving events differ from traditional manual methods in terms of efficiency and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: The method of extracting ice shelf calving events using automated processes is more efficient than traditional manual methods, as it reduces the time-consuming and laborious nature of manual location. It involves processing Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products, using the Canny edge detection algorithm, and simulating coastlines to identify calved areas. This method effectively avoids repetition and omission errors, offering higher accuracy with a positioning error of less than one pixel and a minimum valid extraction area of 0.05 km2.

Comparison.Question: How do datasets derived from Sentinel-1 EW L1 products compare to those from the MEaSUREs Antarctica Ice Velocity Map in terms of their application for studying Antarctic ice sheet dynamics?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets derived from Sentinel-1 EW L1 products provide repeated coverage of the Antarctic coastline and are primarily used for monitoring ice shelf advance and calving events. In contrast, the MEaSUREs Antarctica Ice Velocity Map provides spatial distribution of ice velocity values, which is crucial for understanding the dynamics of ice movement. Both datasets complement each other, with the former focusing on physical changes in ice shelf boundaries and the latter on the movement and velocity of the ice.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies are employed to distinguish between the processes of expansion and calving on the Antarctic ice shelves, and how do these methods contribute to understanding the mass balance of ice shelves?
Interpretation.Answer: Methodologies to distinguish between expansion and calving on Antarctic ice shelves include processing Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products to extract coastline vectors and simulate ice shelf polygons. By analyzing the velocity of each coastline point and simulating their new locations, researchers can differentiate expansion from calving. This approach, involving comparison and correction of polygons, contributes to understanding ice shelf mass balance by providing precise monitoring of calving events and their impact on the net mass loss from the ice sheet.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the challenges in accurately monitoring iceberg calving events using remote sensing data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in accurately monitoring iceberg calving events using remote sensing data arise from the coexistence of ice shelf advances and calving. Manual location of iceberg calving is time-consuming and requires high-quality image texture coherence. The surface textural characteristics of the ice shelves and the quality of the images also pose difficulties in precise monitoring.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is continuous monitoring of iceberg calving events at a continental scale difficult?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Continuous monitoring of iceberg calving events at a continental scale is difficult due to the massive volume of high-resolution remotely sensed data and the lack of efficient extraction methods. This makes detailed and extensive observations time-consuming and laborious.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the errors in the simulated coastline positioning during iceberg calving monitoring?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The positioning errors in the simulated coastline during iceberg calving monitoring are minimized by using a resolution of 75 m images, but challenges such as achieving precise extraction through image quality and texture coherence before and after calving can contribute to errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using high-resolution remotely sensed data in the monitoring of Antarctic ice calving events on the efficiency and accuracy of data collection methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of high-resolution remotely sensed data in monitoring Antarctic ice calving events can enhance the efficiency and accuracy of data collection methods. It allows for the detailed extraction of calving events, including the location, shape, area, and mass of each event. However, it is often time-consuming and laborious due to the massive volume of data and the need for high-quality images for precise monitoring.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the main objectives behind developing a new method to separate the expansion and calving processes of ice shelves in the Antarctic region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main objectives include extracting the location, shape, area, and mass of each calving event to improve understanding of iceberg calving, which is crucial for accurate prediction of climate change impacts on ice sheets.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the challenges in precise monitoring of iceberg calving using remotely sensed data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Addressing these challenges is important because the coexistence of ice shelf advances and calving complicates monitoring, and precise extraction depends on image quality and texture coherence, making it crucial for understanding mass balance and dynamics of Antarctic ice shelves.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of using Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products and MEaSUREs datasets for monitoring Antarctic ice shelf changes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of these datasets is significant because they provide repeated coverage and spatial distribution of ice velocity values, which are essential for accurately detecting calving events and understanding the dynamics of ice shelf changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods can be employed to accurately separate the expansion and calving processes of ice shelves using remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A method proposed involves processing Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products using the Sentinel Application Platform (SNAP) for calibration and terrain correction, followed by extracting and manually modifying coastline vectors using an updated Canny edge detection algorithm. By converting the ice shelf polygon vertices into points and analyzing their movement based on velocity, the method derives a simulated coastline, which is then compared to contemporaneous images to correct and obtain the exact ice shelf polygon, allowing for the extraction of calved-area polygons.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can high-resolution remotely sensed data be systematically preprocessed to facilitate the continuous monitoring of iceberg calving events?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The preprocessing involves using Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products and choosing the Antarctica polar stereographic projections, followed by resampling to a 75 m resolution. The process includes automatic extraction and manual modification of the original coastline benchmark, conversion of polygon vertices into points, and analysis of their movement to derive a simulated coastline. This is then corrected with contemporaneous images to fit the actual coastline position, aiding in the extraction of calved areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to ensure the accurate extraction of iceberg calving events despite the coexistence of ice shelf advances?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure includes using Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products to derive simulated coastlines by converting polygon vertices into points and analyzing their movement. By comparing these with contemporaneous images and correcting the frontal edge, the exact ice shelf polygon is obtained for each year. The subtraction of corrected ice shelf polygons from simulated polygons provides calved-area polygons, effectively avoiding repetition and omission errors.

Enablement.Question: What advancements in remote sensing technologies have enabled the efficient extraction of ice shelf calving events in the Antarctic region?
Enablement.Answer: The use of Sentinel-1 EW L1 ground range detected (GRD) products, processed with the Sentinel Application Platform (SNAP), has enabled efficient extraction by providing high-resolution images that cover the Antarctic coastline repeatedly. This technology allows for detailed monitoring and precise extraction of iceberg calving events.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of automated and manual methods enhance the accuracy of monitoring changes in the Antarctic ice shelf coastline?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of automated methods, such as the updated Canny edge detection algorithm for coastline extraction, alongside manual modifications, allows for precise monitoring of changes. This combination ensures that the simulated coastline closely matches the actual coastline, minimizing errors in detecting calving events.

Enablement.Question: What datasets are essential for determining the spatial distribution of ice velocity in Antarctic ice shelf studies?
Enablement.Answer: The MEaSUREs Antarctica Ice Velocity Map Version 2 is crucial for determining the spatial distribution of ice velocity values, which helps identify the movement and new location of each coastline point during the calving process analysis.

Expectation.Question: Why might the detailed monitoring of iceberg calving be expected to face challenges in terms of image quality and texture coherence?
Expectation.Answer: The detailed monitoring of iceberg calving is complex due to the coexistence of ice shelf advances and calving. Observing calving requires high-quality images and good texture coherence before and after the event to accurately detect changes, as the expansion of ice shelves can obscure the calving events.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges when using high-resolution remotely sensed data for continuous monitoring of iceberg calving events on a continental scale?
Expectation.Answer: The expected challenges include the time-consuming and laborious process due to the massive volume of data and the lack of efficient extraction methods, which makes continuous monitoring difficult.

Judgmental.Question: What do you think are the main challenges in accurately monitoring Antarctic ice sheet calving using remote sensing techniques?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges include the coexistence of ice shelf advances and calving, which complicates the precise monitoring of iceberg calving. The manual location is time-consuming, and achieving precise extraction relies heavily on the surface textural characteristics and quality of images. Furthermore, the image matching method for high-precision monitoring is demanding in terms of image quality and texture coherence before and after calving events.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using the Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products for monitoring changes in the Antarctic ice shelf regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products are effective for monitoring Antarctic ice shelf changes, as they repeatedly cover the coastline and allow for high-resolution analysis. The method used effectively avoids repetition and omission errors during the calved area extraction process, providing positioning errors of less than one pixel and determining a minimum valid extraction area of 0.05 km2.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, could the development of more efficient extraction methods significantly improve the continuity and accuracy of iceberg calving monitoring?
Judgmental.Answer: Yes, developing more efficient extraction methods could significantly enhance the continuity and accuracy of iceberg calving monitoring. Currently, the extraction process is laborious due to the massive volume of high-resolution data and inefficient extraction methods. Improved techniques could streamline this process, allowing for continuous monitoring at a continental scale and better understanding of calving dynamics.

Assertion.Answer: The spatial distribution of ice velocity values is obtained using the MEaSUREs Antarctica Ice Velocity Map Version 2, which provides detailed ice velocity data.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure how high-resolution remotely sensed data is utilized efficiently for continuous monitoring of calving events.
Assertion.Answer: High-resolution remotely sensed data is used by repeatedly covering the Antarctic coastline with Sentinel-1 products and employing advanced image processing methods to extract and analyze the calving events over time.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for monitoring iceberg calving events in the Antarctic ice shelf system.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for monitoring iceberg calving events include processing Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products using the Sentinel Application Platform (SNAP), developed by Brockmann Consult, SkyWatch, and C-S. The process involves calibration, terrain correction, choosing Antarctica polar stereographic projections, and resampling to 75 m resolution. By extracting and modifying coastline vectors using an updated Canny edge detection algorithm, the methods allow for the creation of simulated coastlines and the identification of calving events through comparison.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the main challenges faced in the precise monitoring of iceberg calving and suggest potential improvements in data collection techniques.
Request/Directive.Answer: The main challenges in precise monitoring of iceberg calving include the coexistence of ice shelf advances and calving, the time-consuming nature of manual location efforts, and reliance on image quality and texture coherence. Improvements could involve developing more efficient extraction methods to handle high-resolution data effectively, enhancing image processing algorithms for better texture analysis, and automating the comparison of temporal images to reduce laborious manual efforts.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that could be utilized for expanding research on Antarctic ice shelf calving events and their implications under climate change.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for expanding research on Antarctic ice shelf calving events include the Sentinel-1 EW L1 GRD products, which cover the Antarctic coastline annually, and the MEaSUREs Antarctica Ice Velocity Map Version 2. These datasets provide information on ice velocity values and grounding line data, which are crucial for understanding calving dynamics and their implications under climate change.
